result.name: nela-year-4-hospital-level-data-spreadsheet-2018
result.notes:
Explanatory notes on the NELA Data:
- Timeframe – Data was collected from December 2016 to November 2017
- Please follow this link to see the Inclusion/Exclusion criteria - http://www.nela.org.uk/NELADocs  
- For an explanation as to why these indicators were selected and reported on please see the Fourth Patient Report of the National Emergency Laparotomy Audit – http://www.nela.org.uk/reports  
- Grey rows indicate Hospitals submitting less than ten cases in the Fourth year of data collection
- Cells with N/A mean that Data was not available / Not able to calculate
- Changes to variables:
              - "Proportion of patients reviewed by a consultant surgeon and/or a consultant anaesthetist before emergency laparotomy if pre-operative p-possum mortality risk >= 5%" - This standard has been changed for Year 4 of the NELA data collection, it includes reviews both in person and carried out remotely. 
              - "Time of booking" is no longer part of the NELA data collection. The name of the variable in Year 3 "Proportion of included cases where neither time of decision to operate nor time of booking for theatre was submitted" has therefore been renamed in Year 4 to "Proportion of included cases where no time of decision to operate for theatre was submitted".  Additionally the variable "Proportion of cases where interval from decision to operate (or time of booking) to arrival in theatre was appropriate to documented operative urgency (for cases with urgency <18 hours)" has been renamed in Year 4 to "Proportion of cases where interval from decision to operate to arrival in theatre was appropriate to documented operative urgency (for cases with urgency <18 hours)"

organization.name: healthcare-quality-improvement-partnership
organization.title: Healthcare Quality Improvement Partnership
organization.description:
The Healthcare Quality Improvement Partnership (HQIP) was established in April 2008 to promote quality in healthcare, and in particular to increase the impact that clinical audit has on healthcare quality improvement. HQIP is an independent organisation led by the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, The Royal College of Nursing, and National Voices and it works in partnership with patients and healthcare professionals to influence and improve healthcare practice at all levels. 

HQIP commissions, manages, supports, and promotes national and local programmes of quality improvement. This includes the national clinical audit programmes, the Clinical Outcome Review Programmes and the National Joint Registry on behalf of NHS England and other healthcare departments and organisations.  

In compliance with its commissioning status, HQIP:

• Uses best management and procurement practice to ensure robust results and actionable recommendations.

• Ensures patients and carers remain at the heart of its work through continued, strategic involvement in all relevant processes and projects.  

• Supports professionals to review and improve their practice by providing education and training programmes, and opportunities to share best practice as part of promoting an integrated approach to quality improvement.

• Works to inform and influence national healthcare policy by effectively communicating its work and that of its partners.

• Encourages wide use of robust data for quality improvement of care, offering patient choice, promoting patient safety, supporting revalidation and service accreditation, commissioning, service redesign, and research.

Further information about the HQIP Board, the team, and the organisations that HQIP work with is available on the HQIP website at http://www.hqip.org.uk/about-us/.
